bibl.title: Letter from Adrian Macia to Philip Showalter Hench, March 9, 1942

div1.p: Macia returns a check for the purchase of a small lot of land at the former site of Camp Lazear. He is concerned that this lot might interfere with his quarry or with the entrance to the land in the back of it. He is willing to reconsider until definite plans have been made for the memorialization of the site. Macia informs Hench that some small repairs have been done at Building No. 1.

div1.head: Letter from Adrian Macia to Philip Showalter Hench, March 9, 1942
div1.opener:
ADRIAN MACIA
INGENIERO CIVIL Y ARQUITECTO
HABANA
Habana, March 9, 1942.
Doctor P.S. Hench, M.D.,
Rochester, Minnesota.
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I want to acknowledge receipt of yours dated January
30th. enclosing a check to my order for the amount of $150. Your check
I am returning to you now as I could not accept it for the purchase of
land as you intended. In my last letter I told you that in case you went
ahead with your projects we would probably present that small lot of land
and for this reason I cannot accept the check you sent.

Regarding the lot of land you have outlined in the map I am sorry to
say I dont think I could very well give you a price for it as I will not
be willing to sell unless some definite projects were on the way of
realization, and then you can be sure that the price we will set for this
lot would be a very reasonable one not trying to take any advantage, but
we will have to consider whether this lot would interfere with our quarry
or with the entrance to the land back of it.

So I think that more definite studies have to be made before I could
give you a proper answer.

Regarding what you ask me about Dr. Ponce, I do not know him, but I
can inform you that something has been published some time ago in the
local press and also by radio; but I know that Dr. Marruz at the time
Minister of Health visited the site of camp Lazear, but nothing else has
been published or said as far as I know, and Dr. Marruz is now no longer
Minister of Health. I will be very pleased to inform you of any further
developments along this line.

Since my last letter I have learned that some small repair was done
to the little house, I suppose by Mr. Moran so I am sorry about my
information in my last letter that nothing had been done.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, Adrian Maciá. Enclosed: check, map.
